text: [Music]
We have a fairly diverse congregation,
but my guess is that our our demographic
looks young, but Manhattan is a young
demographic. So, I'm not sure I've I'm
Look, I'm old and I'm not sure that
actually I'm I have ever pitched to
young people or sought young people. I'm
actually just communicating my message
in a place where there are a lot of
young people. So, that there they
are. We in Manhattan, we have actually
started about 10 or 11 what we call
daughter churches. Churches that spun
right out of Redeemer to start churches
in other parts of the city. Um in other
cities we started probably another
60 churches in various forms. Uh and the
model is uh very very orthodox in your
beliefs. So when you
actually very orthodox in your beliefs.
So when you actually um uh ask people
what they believe, it's very
historically traditional. But in the
expression of it, the communication of
it, and the attitude toward the whole
city, very engaged, very uh open,
servant-hearted, very u uh very much
seeking the peace and prosperity of the
whole city. So not
tribal. I'll put it like this. Here's
the model. Secularism, I think, tends to
make people selfish.
It tends to make people say, "Well,
basically I have to decide what's right
or wrong for me." Uh, religion tends to
make people tribal like we have the
truth. I'm trying to find a way of
helping people understand the gospel of
Christianity that uh on the one hand
gives people uh a truth that is more
important than their own individual
happiness. So they're living for
something more important than they're
fulfilling their own needs, but doesn't
turn them into a little tribe of people
that feels like we're right, everybody
else is wrong, and so you can all go to
hell unless you join us. So I'd like to
get away from the selfishness and the
tribalism and that approach to
Christianity. Yes, I I do think it goes
very well in in urban areas. And there's
a lot of young people looking for
meaning in life, but also an attitude
toward the city which is one of service,
not one of a a fortress
mentality. We're pretty traditionally
Presbyterian, but I think the average
person who comes uh wouldn't think of
themselves as a
Presbyterian. Uh we don't beat people
over the head with how different we are
from Lutheran or Methodists or Baptists.
That's all. If you come into the church
far enough, you'll find that our
traditions, our way of governing, uh
many of our uh theological distinctives
are perfectly presbyter.
